resources.string: X Games Norway are being held in the middle of Oslo.
Norway\'s largest festival for the lesbian and gay population, with concerts, art exhibits, shows, film screenings, parties and political debates.
Traditional festival at Akershus fortress that takes you back in time to the period when Oslo became Norway\'s capital.
The big children\'s parade and an abundance of flags are the central elements of Oslo\'s 17 May celebrations.
Oslo Film Festival is a boutique independent film festival hosted in Oslo.
In August every year the Øya Festival it draws around 60,000 music lovers to Oslo\'s east side.
Ekebergrestauranten has the choice between the outdoor restaurant, romantic veranda, cafe, sophisticated dining room or the private chamber.
Maaemo is a dining experience, with the owners recommending diners set aside a whole evening in order to fully appreciate and savor the set menu.
Hanami is a Japanese fusion restaurant, and the only one in Oslo to practice the robata technique of grilling meat and fish.
Hos Thea is aiming at providing a gourmet meal for a reasonable price in a homey environment.
High-ceilinged, contemporary Japanese restaurant with central bar, specializing in sushi and sashimi.
An informal restaurant and bar with Japanese style food and drinks.
The Astrup Fearnley Collection is a collection of modern and contemporary art.
A Sculpture park designed by world-renowned architect Renzo Piano.
The Viking Ship Museum shows discoveries from the Gokstad, Oseberg and Tune ships.
One of the world\'s oldest and largest open-air museums, with 155 traditional houses from all parts of Norway and a stave church from the year 1200.
The largest collection of items from pre-historic times and the Middle Ages found in Norway.
Norwegian Museum of Science and Technology
The national museum for technology, industry, science and medicine.
Ruins from the first settlers in Oslo, from around 1000 AD to 1300 AD.
Kvadraturen was King Christian IV\'s town from the Renaissance.
Akershus Castle and Fortress was built during the 1300s by king Håkon V.
Æreslunden is Norway\'s main honorary burial ground. Famous Norwegians like Edvard Munch and Henrik Ibsen is buried here.
Akerselva is a river that runs through the centre of Oslo, and has a vibrant history.
The house was built in 1800 as sawmiller\'s house, and is named after a character from Oskar Braaten's books.
